File.Title: Mamillary Body in the Rat: Topography and Synaptology of Projections From the Subicular Complex, Prefrontal Cortex, and Midbrain Tegmentum
File.Authors: GARY V. ALLEN AND DAVID A. HOPKINS

Abstract.S: The retrograde and anterograde transport of horseradish peroxidase conjugated to wheat germ agglutinin (WGA-HRP) has been used to trace afferent connections of the rat mamillary body (MB) at the light and electron microscopic levels.
Injections of WGA-HRP into different parts of the MB resulted in heavy retrograde labeling in the subicular complex, medial prefrontal cortex, and dorsal and ventral tegmental nuclei.
Injections of WGA-HRP into each of these brain regions, respectively, resulted in anterograde labeling with specific distributions and characteristic synaptic organizations in the MB.

Projections from the rostrodorsal and caudoventral subiculum terminated in a topographically organized laminar fashion in the medial mamillary nucleus bilaterally, whereas afferent projections from the presubiculum and parasubiculum terminated only in the lateral mamillary nucleus.

Labeled axon terminals which originated from the subicular complex were characterized by round vesicles and formed asymmetric synaptic junctions with small-diameter dendrites and dendritic spines in the medial and lateral mamillary nuclei.
Projections from the prefrontal cortex originated mainly in the infralimbic area and to a lesser degree in the prelimbic and anterior cingulate areas.

Injections of tracer into these brain regions gave rise to dense labeling of axon terminals in the medial mamillary nucleus, pars medianus, and in the anterior dorsomedial portion of the pars medialis.
The labeled terminals were characterized by round vesicles and formed asymmetric synaptic junctions with small-diameter dendrites and dendritic spines.

Projections from the dorsal tegmental nucleus terminated in the ipsilateral lateral mamillary nucleus, whereas afferent projections from the anterior and posterior subnuclei of the ventral tegmental nucleus terminated topographically in the medial mamillary nucleus.

The ventral tegmental nucleus, pars anterior projected to the midline region of the medial nucleus and the dorsolateral and ventromedial subdivisions of the pars posterior projected to medial and lateral parts of the medial nucleus, respectively.

In contrast to the synaptic morphology of subicular complex and medial prefrontal cortex axon terminals in the MB, labeled axon terminals in the MB which originated from the midbrain tegmentum were characterized by pleomorphic vesicles and formed symmetric synaptic junctions with neuronal somata and proximal dendrites as well as distal dendrites and dendritic spines.

The morphological differences among axon terminals of afferent projections from the subicular complex and the medial prefrontal cortex compared to those from the midbrain tegmentum suggest that the inputs differ in terms of excitatory or inhibitory effects on MB neurons.
It is proposed that cortical, subcortical, and brainstem connections of the MB form three distinct neural circuits which may represent anatomical substrates for different functional activities.

Introduction.S: The mamillary body (MB) has been implicated in a wide variety of diverse functions for which the neural basis is poorly understood.

These functions include learning and memory (Rosenstock et al., '77; Holmes et al., '83a,b; Aggleton and Mishkin, '85), sexual behavior (Lisk, '66), defensive behavior (Krieckhaus, '67), the regulation of autonomic activity (Cragg and Hamlyn, '59; Faiers et al., '76), and the initiation and propagation of seizure activity (Green and Morin, '53; Jinnai et al., '69; Mirski and Ferrendelli, '83, '84, '87).

In keeping with the diversity of functions attributed to the MB, this structure receives afferent fibers from widespread regions such as the hippocampal formation (Guillery, '56; Nauta, '56; Valenstein and Nauta, '59; Raisman et al., '66; Meibach and Siegel, '75, '77; Swanson and Cowan, '75, W), prefrontal cort.ex (Saper, personal communication; Wouterlood et al., '87), and midbrain tegmentum (Guillery, '56; Cowan et al., '64; Petrovick9, '73, '85; Hayakawa and Zyo, '84; Liu et al., '84; Shibata, '87).

The MB also has efferent projections to the anterior thalamus (Guillery, '57; Cruce, '75; Watanabe and Kawana, '80; Seki and Zyo, '84) and midbrain (Guillery, '57; Nauta, '58; Cruce, '77; Liu et al., '84), most of which arise from neurons with collateral projections to both thalamus and midbrain (Takeuchi et al., '85).
Relatively little is known regarding the synaptic organization of the MB.
In a recent study, we have described the cytoarchitecture and normal ultrastructure of the MB in the rat (Allen and Hopkins, '88).

The purpose of the present study was to identify the synaptic organization of major afferent systems to the MB in order to provide an anatomical framework for a better understanding of its functional roles.

As a necessary prelude to electron microscopic analysis, the locations of the cells of origin and the distributions of afferents in the MB were confirmed at the light microscopic level by using the retrograde and anterograde transport of wheat germ agglutinin-horseradish peroxidase (WGA-HRP).

Methods.S: MATERIALS AND METHODS
The subjects were 89 adult male, Wistar rats weighing 250-500 g.
Stereotaxic injections of WGA-HRP were made into the MB, subicular complex, medial prefrontal cortex, and midbrain.
The atlas of the rat brain by Paxinos and Watson ('86) was used to determine coordinates for stereotaxic injections.
The animals were anesthetized with sodium pentobarbital (40-60 mg/kg IP) for all surgical procedures.
Injections of 0.01-0.12 ~1 of 1-59; aqueous solutions of WGA-HRP were made by using a 1 p1 Hamilton syringe fitted with a mineral-oil-filled glass micropipette (tip diameter 40-100 Fm).
To obtain small injections of WGA-HRP, the exact volume of tracer to be injected followed by a small volume of light mineral oil were taken up into the glass micropipette.

With this procedure, mineral oil separated the WGA-HRP from the tip of the micropipette and, thus, diffusion of the WGA-HRP from the micropipette was reduced as the micropipette was lowered into the brain.
The micropipette was positioned in the brain for at least 20 minutes while the WGA-HRP was slowly pressure injected.

Injections of WGA-HRP into brain regions adjacent to the MB, subicular complex, medial prefrontal cortex, and midbrain, or into the ventricular system, served as controls for uptake of tracer by axons of passage or nonspecific uptake of tracer.

For the electron microscopic analysis, controls included sections from the contralateral side of the MB following unilateral WGA-HRP injections into the midbrain, sections through the MB which were not incubated in tetramethyl benzidine (TMB) and 3',3'-diaminobenzidine (DAB), and sections from the brains of normal unoperated rats.
This control material ensured that WGA-HRP reaction products were distinguishable from other electrondense structures or endogenous peroxidase activity.
Light microscopy
Injections of WGA-HRP were made into the MB (N = 16), subicular complex (N = 18), medial prefrontal cortex (N = 4), and midbrain (N = 16).

After 1-3 days, the animals were perfused with 500 ml of normal saline and 0.5% magnesium chloride followed by 1000 ml of 1.0% paraformaldehyde and 1.25% glutaraldehyde in 0.1 M phosphate buffer (pH 7.4).
The brains were removed and placed in 30% sucrose-phosphate buffer overnight before being cut into series of 40 pm-thick sections with a freezing microtome.
The sections were incubated in TMB according to the method of Mesulam ('78).
One series of sections was counterstained with 1% neutral red and a second series was left unstained.
Electron microscopy
Injections of WGA-HRP were made into the subicular complex (N = 12), medial prefrontal cortex (N = 5), and midbrain (N = 18).
After 1-3 days, the animals were perfused with 300 ml of 0.15 M phosphate buffer (pH 7.4) followed by 1000 ml of 0.5% paraformaldehyde and 2.5% glutaraldehyde in phosphate buffer (pH 7.4).
The brains were removed and placed in 0.15 M phosphate buffer prior to cutting 100 pm sections through the region of the MB with a vibratome (Lancer).
Two different histochemical procedures were used to study anterograde and retrograde labeling in the MB at the electron microscopic level.

One series of sections was treated with DAB (Itoh et al., '79) as the chromogen and a second series of sections was treated with TMB (Mesulam, '78) followed by a second incubation in DAB (Rye et al., '84; Lemann et al., '85).

Rye et al. ('84) originally showed that stabilization of the highly sensitive TMB reaction product with a sequential incubation in DAB was useful for combined use in anterograde and retrograde tracing and subsequent immunohistochemical staining procedures.

Lemann et al. ('85) showed that stabilization of TMB reaction product with a sequential incubation in DAB was also useful for visualization of anterograde and retrograde labeling at the electron microscopic level.

In the present study, the pH of the acetate buffer used in the TMB incubation medium was adjusted from pH 3.5 up to pH 7.0 in order to ascertain the optimal development of reaction product along with the best tissue preservation.
Regions containing the MB were cut into blocks and processed for electron microscopy according to standard methods (see Materials and Methods, Allen and Hopkins, '88).
Ultrathin sections were cut with a diamond knife and stained with uranyl acetate-lead citrate or left unstained before examination with a Zeiss EM 10A electron microscope.
Nomenclature

The nomenclature of the subicular complex used in the present study corresponds with Meibach and Siegel's ('77) modifications of the initial descriptions of the hippocampal formation by Lorente de N6 ('34).
The nomenclature used for the prefrontal cortex follows that proposed by Krettek and Price ('77).
Quantitative analyses
The diameters of labeled axon terminals were calculated by taking the mean of the long and short axes of the terminals as measured directly from electron micrographs (final magnification ~16,000).

Since the MB is known to have reciprocal projections to the midbrain (Guillery, '57; Cruce, '77; Takeuchi et al., '85), estimates of the numbers of labeled and unlabeled neurons in the medial and lateral mamillary nuclei were made from 1 pm-thick plastic sections (toluidine blue stained) following injections of WGA-HRP into the midbrain.
Only perikarya which were sectioned through the nucleolus were counted.
Approximately 1,900 cells were counted from sections cut from selected rostral to caudal levels of the MB in eight animals.

Results.S: RESULTS

TTE.S: in the present study , injections of wga - hrp into the region of the mb resulted in dense retrograde labeling in the subicular complex , medial prefrontal cortex , and dorsal and ventral tegmental nuclei .
fewer retrogradely labeled perikarya were observed in the nucleus of the diagonal band of broca , and small numbers of widely scattered labeled perikarya were found in the lateral hypothalamus .
dense anterograde labeling was observed in the anterior thalamus , dorsal and ventral tegmental nuclei , nucleus reticularis tegmenti pontis , and medial pontine nuclei .

Results.S: Merents from the subicular complex

TTE.S: Light microscopy.
figure 1 shows the differential distribution of retrogradely labeled neurons in the subicular complex following injections of wga - hrp into the medial and lateral mamillary nuclei .

in one of the cases illustrated in figure 1 , the injection site ( inset ) was centered in the midline of the medial mamillary nucleus and included most of the subnuclei of the medial nucleus bilaterally .
the lateral mamillary nucleus was spared but there was some spread from the principal injection site dorsally into the medial portion of the supramamillary nucleus .

large numbers of retrogradely labeled perikarya were found bilaterally in all layers of the dorsal and ventral portions of the subiculum but no labeled cells were found in the presubiculum or parasubiculum ( figs . 1 , 2 ) .
a few retrogradely labeled neurons were also found in the deep layers of the retrosplenial granular cortex ( figs . lb , 2 ) .
in the second case illustrated in figure 1 , the injection site ( inset ) was located mainly in the lateral mamillary nucleus with a slight involvement of the lateral part of the medial nucleus .
in addition , there was some spread from the injection site dorsally into the lateral portion of the supramamillary nucleus and lateral hypothalamus .
numerous retrogradely labeled perikarya were found mainly ipsilaterally in the presubiculum and parasubiculum ( figs . 1 , 3 ) .
a few labeled neurons were also found in ipsilateral dorsal subiculum as well as in the contralateral presubiculum .
following injections of wga - hrp into the subicular complex , anterograde labeling was distributed in distinct horizontal bands or layers across the mb bilaterally ( fig . 4 ) .

the horizontal layers of anterograde labeling were present primarily in either dorsal or intermediate or ventral parts of the medial mamillary nucleus depending on the locations of the injection sites in the rostral to caudal parts of the subicular complex .
figure 4a - d shows the results from a representative case in which wga - hrp was injected into the rostrodorsal portion of the subiculum .
the resultant anterograde labeling was present in the medial mamillary nucleus bilaterally and formed a horizontal layer across the dorsal portion of the medial mamillary nucleus ( fig . 4b - d ) .

the anterograde labeling was moderate to light in the anterio( fig . 4b ) and middle ( fig . 4c ) thirds of the medial nucleus and
heavy in the posterior third of the mb ( fig . 4d ) .
figure 4e - h shows the results from a representative case in which wga - hrp was injected into the caudoventral part of the subicular complex which included the presubiculum and parasubiculum .

in this case , heavy anterograde labeling was present in the ventral portion of the posterior half of the medial mamillary nucleus bilaterally ( fig . 4g , h ) , whereas moderate to light anterograde labeling was present in the intermediate and dorsal parts of the anterior half of the medial nucleus bilaterally ( fig . 4f , g ) .
the pars medianus showed very sparse or no anterograde labeling following injections in the caudoventral part of the subicular complex ( fig . 4f ) .
moderate to light anterograde labeling was also found in the lateral mamillary nucleus mainly ipsilaterally ( fig . 4g ) .

cases in which the wga - hrp injections into the subicular complex did not involve the presubiculum and parasubiculum showed no anterograde labeling in the lateral mamillary nucleus ( fig . 4a - d ) .
Electron microscopy.
following injections of wgahrp into the subicular complex , labeled axons and axon terminals were observed in both the medial ( figs . 5 - 8 ) and lateral ( fig . 6c ) mamillary nuclei .

when dab was used as the chromogen , labeled axon terminals were characterized by the presence of small amounts of electron - dense reaction product which were located in membrane - bound , lysosomal - like structures ( fig . 5 ) .

Identification of labeled axon terminals following DAB histochemistry required careful study of low-contrast, unstained sections with the electron microscope because in stained sections the DAB reaction product, although darker, resembled the staining seen in normal lysosomes.
in contrast , when the tmb - dab procedure was used , amorphous patches of electron - dense reaction product were found in axons and axon terminals in the mb ( figs . 6 - 8 ) .

the tmb - dab - labeled axon terminals could be easily identified in stained sections at low magnifications because the tmb - dab reaction product formed relatively large complexes and did not resemble normal tissue organelles ( fig . 7 ) .
There were, however, some disadvantages with the TMB-DAB procedure in comparison to the DAB procedure.

for example , tissue elements were less well preserved and the reaction product was usually so large that it tended to obscure the contents of the axon terminals and the morphology of synaptic junctions following incubations in the standard tmb incubation medium ( acetate buffer ph 3 . 5 - 4 . 0 ) ( fig . 6a ) .
These problems were reduced when the pH of the acetate buffer used in the TMB incubations was made less acidic (pH 4.6-6.0).

this simple modification of the tmb procedure resulted in a noticeable reduction in the amount of reaction product within the axon terminals , allowing visualization of synaptic vesicles and the morphology of synaptic junctions along with a much improved preservation of neural elements ( fig . 6b - d ) .
The number of labeled axon terminals observed at the electron microscopic level was markedly decreased when the pH of the acetate buffer was greater than 6.0.

labeled axon terminals from the subicular complex ranged in diameter from 0 . 8 to 2 . 0 pm , contained mainly round vesicles ( diameter = 40 nm ) , and formed asymmetric synaptic junctions mainly with small - diameter ( less than 2 pm ) dendrites and dendritic spines .
individual labeled axon terminals occasionally formed synaptic contacts with two adjacent dendrites ( fig . 8 ) .
labeled axon terminals from the subicular complex only rarely contained pleomorphic vesicles and formed synaptic junctions with neuronal somata or proximal dendrites .
unlabeled axon terminals with pleomorphic vesicles and symmetric synaptic junctions with neuronal elements were , nonetheless , readily identified in this material .

many labeled axon terminals appeared to form two separate synaptic specializations on individual dendritic profiles ( figs . 5 , 6b , d , 8a ) , but serial sectioning of several labeled merents from the medial prefrontal cortex

Results.S: Light microscopy.

TTE.S: the distributions of retrogradely labeled neurons in the medial prefrontal cortex were mapped following injections of wga - hrp into the mb .

figure 9 shows the results from a representative case in which retrograde labeling in the medial prefrontal cortex ( figs . 9a , b , 10 ) was obtained following an injection of wga - hrp into the medial mamillary nucleus ( fig . 9c ) .

Results.S: terminals revealed that two apparently distinct synaptic specializations on the same dendrite were parts of a single continuous synaptic specialization (Fig. 8).

TTE.S: the injection was centered in the medial part of the medial mamillary nucleus with some spread of reaction product laterally into the lateral parts of the medial mamillary nucleus and dorsally into the medial portion of the supramamillary nucleus .

the retrogradely labeled cells in the prefrontal cortex were pyramidal - shaped ( fig . 9b ) and were distributed from the rostral limit of the prefrontal cortex to a level just rostral to the genu of the corpus callosum ( fig . 10 ) .

most of the retrogradely labeled neurons were located in the deep layers of the infralimbic area while fewer labeled neurons were found rostrally and dorsally in or near layer v of the prelimbic and anterior cingulate areas .
a few labeled neurons were also found lateral and ventral to the tenia tecta .
some of the latter cells were located in the caudal end of the infralimbic cortex where they approached the rostralmost extent of the vertical limb of the diagonal band of broca .
after unilateral injections of wga - hrp into the medial prefrontal cortex ( fig .
iia ) , dense anterograde and retrograde labeling was observed in the caudal and lateral hypothalamus ( fig . llb , c ) .

the injection site shown in figure 11a was centered in the medial wall of the prefrontal cortex with some spread dorsally into the medial precentral area , laterally into the claustrum and caudate / putamen , and ventrally into the region of the tenia tecta .
dense anterograde labeling was present along the dorsal margin of the medial mamillary nucleus and in the pars medianus bilaterally ( fig . 11b , c ) .
dense anterograde labeling was also found in the medial forebrain bundle and the medial part of the cerebral peduncle ( fig .
IlC).

in addition , anterograde and retrograde labeling were found mainly in the lateral portions of the supramamillary nucleus and along the lateral and ventral margins of the mb in the tuberomamillary nucleus, mainly ipsilaterally ( fig . 11b , c ) .

em-tte.S: following wga - hrp injections into the medial prefrontal cortex , electron - dense reaction product was found in axon terminals in the medial mamillary nucleus , pars medianus , and along the dorsal border of the pars medialis ( fig . 12 ) .
The distribution of labeled fibers observed in the MB at the electron microscopic level corresponded well with that observed at the light microscopic level.

The labeled synaptic profiles were usually small (diameter of less than 2 pm), contained mainly round vesicles, and formed asymmetric synaptic junctions with smalldiameter dendrites (Fig. 12) and dendritic spines.

Results.S: Reciprocal connections between the MB and the midbrain
Light microscopy.
figure 13 shows the results from a representative case following an injection of wga - hrp into the medial mamillary nucleus .
the injection site ( fig . 13a ) was centered in the midline of the mb including the pars medianus and pars medialis rostrally and the pars posterior caudally .
there was some spread from the principal injection site laterally into the pars lateralis and dorsally into the medial parts of the supramamillary nucleus .
dense anterograde and retrograde labeling were present in the anterior ( fig . 13b ) and posterior ( fig . 13c ) parts of the ventral tegmental nucleus .
the labeled cells in the posterior part of the ventral tegmental nucleus formed a compact cluster dorsolaterally with fewer labeled cells being present ventromedially .
dense anterograde labeling was located in the medial pontine nuclei ( fig . 13b ) and the dorsomedial part of the nucleus reticularis tegmenti pontis ( fig . 13c ) .
a few retrogradely labeled cells were also located in the dorsal and median raphe nuclei , laterodorsal tegmental nucleus , and the locus coeruleus .
there was no anterograde or retrograde labeling in the dorsal tegmental nucleus .

after injections of wga - hrp into the lateral mamillary nucleus ( see fig . 3b ) , dense retrograde labeling was found in the ventral portion of the dorsal tegmental nucleus ipsilaterally ( fig . 14a ) , and moderate anterograde labeling was located in both the dorsal and ventral parts of the dorsal tegmental nucleus ipsilaterally .

in addition , there was heavy retrograde labeling in the ventromedial part of the posterior ventral tegmental nucleus , whereas the dorsolateral part of the ventral tegmental nucleus contained only a few retrogradely labeled cells ipsilaterally ( fig . 14b ) .

because the ventral tegmental nucleus projects to the medial nucleus and not the lateral mamillary nucleus ( cowan et al . , ' 64 hayakawa and zyo , ' 84 takeuchi et al . , ' 85 shibata , ' 87 ) , the retrograde labeling seen in the ventral tegmental nucleus in this case was due to that part of the wga - hrp injection site which involved the lateral part of the medial mamillary nucleus ( see fig . 3b ) .
a few retrogradely labeled cells were also present in the anterior ventral tegmental nucleus , dorsal and median raphe nuclei , laterodorsal tegmental nucleus , and locus coeruleus .
in addition , dense anterograde labeling was observed in the dorsomedial part of the nucleus reticularis tegmenti pontis ipsilaterally and the medial pontine nuclei bilaterally .
the distribution of anterograde and retrograde labeling in the mb was studied following injections of wga - hrp into selected parts of the midbrain tegmentum .

in figure 15a - d , the injection was centered in the ipsilateral ventral tegmental nucleus and included parts of adjacent tegmental structures such as the dorsal and median raphe nuclei , the dorsolateral tegmental nucleus , and the pontine reticular formation .
there was some spread of tracer caudally into the region of the dorsal tegmental nucleus .
dense anterograde and retrograde labeling were present in the caudal mb ( fig . 15b ) as well as in more rostra1 parts of the medial mamillary nucleus ipsilaterally ( fig . 15c ) .
dense anterograde labeling was also present in the midline nucleus pars medianus bilaterally ( fig . 15d ) .
light anterograde and retrograde labeling was present in the ipsilateral lateral mamillary nucleus ( fig . 15c ) .
in addition , moderate to light anterograde and retrograde labeling was present in the supramamillary and tuberomamillary nuclei .
A
B C D

following unilateral injections of wga - hrp into the region of the anterior ventral tegmental nucleus , dense anterograde labeling was observed in the pars medianus and midline portions of the pars medialis bilaterally ( fig . 15e ) .
moderate to light retrograde labeling was also found in the medial and lateral parts of the medial mamillary nucleus and along the ventral and lateral borders of the lateral nucleus .
following injections of wga - hrp into the region of the dorsal tegmental nucleus , anterograde and retrograde labeling was found in the lateral mamillary nucleus ipsilaterally .
Electron microscopy.

following injections of wgahrp into the midbrain , anterograde and retrograde labeling was found in the lateral ( figs . 16a , 18b , 19c ) and medial ( figs . 16b , c , 17 , 18a , 19a , b ) mamillary nuclei .

when dab was used as the chromogen , neuronal somata ( figs . 16a , 18b , c ) , dendrites ( fig . 16c ) , axons , and axon terminals ( fig . 16 ) contained electron - dense reaction product which was located in membrane - bound , lysosomal like structures .

In contrast to the labeling observed in the MB following DAB histochemistry, after sequential TMB-DAB histochemistry the reaction product observed in neuronal somata (Figs. 17, HA), dendrites, axons, and axon terminals (Figs. 17B, 19) was characterized by amorphous patches of electron-dense material that were often associated with intact or disrupted electron-dense lysosomes.

labeled axon terminals in the mb which originated from the midbrain were usually less than 2 km in diameter , contained mainly pleomorphic vesicles , and formed symmetric synaptic junctions with labeled and unlabeled neuronal somata ( figs . 16 , 17 ) , proximal and distal dendrites ( figs . 16 , 19 ) , and dendritic spines ( fig . 19a ) .
individual labeled terminals occasionally synapsed with two adjacent dendrites ( fig . 19b ) .
only one of 137 labeled axon terminals from the midbrain contained round vesicles and formed an asymmetric synaptic junction with a dendrite .
All other axon terminals with round vesicles and asymmetric synapses were unlabeled and usually synapsed with dendrites and dendritic spines (cf.
Allen and Hopkins, '88).
following injections of wga - hrp into the midbrain , numerous retrogradely labeled perikarya were found in the lateral mamillary nucleus and each subnucleus of the medial mamillary nucleus .

estimates of the numbers of labeled and unlabeled perikarya in 1 pm - thick sections revealed that 8090% of the cells in the lateral nucleus and 80 - 9070 of the cells in each subnucleus of the medial mamillary nucleus were retrogradely labeled .
electron - dense reaction product was found in both medium - sized ( diameter 16 . 0 - 30 . 0 pm ) ( fig . 17a ) and small ( diameter 9 . 0 - 15 . 9 pm ) ( fig . 18 ) neurons .
labeled neurons in both the lateral and the medial mamillary nuclei were characterized by an eccentrically located nucleus which exhibited one or more invaginations of the nuclear envelope .
the nucleus usually contained fine chromatin , a spherical nucleolus , and the occasional dense clump of fine chromatin - like material .

the cytoplasm of labeled neurons contained varying amounts of rough and smooth endoplasmic reticulum , golgi complexes , mitochon dria , ribosomes , lysosomes , lipofuscin granules , clear vesicles , occasional dense - cored vesicles , multivesicular bodies , vacuoles , microtubules , and neurofilaments .

the cytoplasm of medium - sized cells usually contained aggregates of rough endoplasmic reticulum which were arranged into parallel arrays of cisternae , while the rough endoplasmic reticulum of small neurons was sparse and loosely scattered in the cytoplasm .
the plasma membranes of labeled neurons were often closely apposed to those of other unlabeled ( fig . 17a ) and labeled neurons ( fig . 18a ) .

Discussion.S: DISCUSSION

The present study shows 1) that the subicular complex, medial prefrontal cortex, and dorsal and ventral tegmental nuclei have dense afferent projections to the MB, 2) that the terminal fields of these afferent projections are highly topographically organized in the MB, 3) that axon terminals which originate from the subicular complex and the medial prefrontal cortex are characterized mainly by round vesicles and form asymmetric synaptic junctions with small-diameter dendrites and dendritic spines, and 4) that axon terminals which originate from the midbrain tegmentum are characterized by pleomorphic vesicles and form symmetric synaptic junctions with neuronal somata and proximal dendrites as well as distal dendrites and dendritic spines.

An analysis of the patterns of anterograde labeling observed in the MB in the present study following injections of tracer into the subicular complex, medial prefrontal cortex, and midbrain tegmentum indicates that the various subnuclei of the MB constitute foci for distinct topographically organized neural circuits with these diverse brain regions.
Merents from the subicular complex

With regard to the cells of origin in the subicular complex, the present study shows that cells in most layers of the dorsal and ventral subiculum project to the medial mamillary nucleus, whereas cells in the deep layers of the presubiculum and parasubiculum project to the lateral mamillary nucleus.
These results confirm and extend findings of Meibach and Siegel ('77) and Swanson and Cowan ('77).

However, Meibach and Siegel ('77) indicated that cells in the presubiculum and parasubiculum project to the caudal part of the medial mamillary nucleus bilaterally, whereas Swanson and Cowan ('77) reported that anterograde labeling in the lateral mamillary nucleus was consistently present only when injections of tracer involved the presubiculum and parasubiculum as in the present study.
A few cells were retrogradely labeled in the retrosplenial granular cortex following injections of tracer into the region of the medial mamillary nucleus.

A projection to the MB from the retrosplenial cortex has not previously been reported in the rat (Meibach and Siegel, '77; Swanson and Cowan, '77) or cat (Edinger et al., '79) although a projection from the retrosplenial cortex to the MB has been identified in the rhesus monkey (Ekstein and Rosene, '84).

However, it is likely that many, if not all, of the retrogradely labeled cells observed in the retrosplenial cortex in the present study project to nuclei adjacent to the MB such as the supramamillary nucleus and/or tuberomamillary nucleus since retrogradely labeled cells were also usually present in the retrosplenial granular cortex when injections spread into these regions and in control injections in these areas.

We have identified the locations of neurons in different parts of the subicular complex with projections to the medial and lateral mamillary nuclei and have confirmed that afferents from the subicular complex are topographically organized in a laminar fashion in the medial mamillary nucleus.

It is also important to note that the pars medianus contained only very sparse or no anterograde labeling following WGA-HRP injections into different parts of the subicular complex, which confirms the anterograde tracing studies of Guillery ('56) and Meibach and Siegel ('77).
The latter finding is significant in the context of the distribution of afferent fibers from the medial prefrontal cortex and the midbrain tegmentum.
Merents from the medial prefrontal cortex

The present results show that projection neurons in the medial prefrontal cortex have a dense terminal field in the pars medianus and the dorsal border of the anterior third of the medial mamillary nucleus.

This finding corresponds with a recent HRP transport study of Saper (personal communication) and the study of Wouterlood et al. ('87) in which the anterograde transport of the lectin Phaseolus uulgaris leucoagglutinin was used.

A comparison of the distributions of afferent fibers in the medial mamillary nucleus which originate from the medial prefrontal cortex and the subicular complex indicates that the terminal fields have very little or no overlap in the MB.
The pars medianus of the medial mamillary nucleus receives a dense projection from the medial prefrontal cortex and only a very sparse projection from the subicular complex.

Thus, neural circuits which include the medial prefrontal cortex and the subicular complex may be segregated in part on the basis of their connections with different subnuclei of the medial mamillary nucleus.
The idea of separate neural circuits which include different subnuclei in the MB will be elaborated later in the discussion.
Reciprocal connections between the MB and the midbrain

The present study is in agreement with previous studies (Guillery, '57; Cruce, '77; Liu et al., '84; Hopkins et al., '85; Takeuchi et al., '85) regarding projections from the lateral and medial mamillary nuclei to the dorsal and ventral tegmental nuclei, respectively, and projections from both the lateral and medial mamillary nuclei to the dorsomedial part of the nucleus reticularis tegmenti pontis and the medial pontine nuclei.

Furthermore, the present results have confirmed that the reciprocal connections between the MB and the midbrain tegmentum are highly topographically organized (Guillery, '57; Cruce, '77; Takeuchi et al., '85; Shibata, '87).

Following injections of WGA-HRP into the MB, retrogradely labeled cells were also present outside the dorsal and ventral tegmental nuclei in the dorsal and median raphe nuclei, laterodorsal tegmental nucleus, and locus coeruleus.

Retrograde labeling in these regions was most dense when the MB injections were relatively large and the injection sites involved structures adjacent to the MB such as the premamillary, supramamillary, and tuberomamillary nuclei.

Since dense anterograde labeling was found in the dorsal premamillary nucleus (Shibata, '87) and moderate to light anterograde labeling was found in the supramamillary and tuberomamillary nuclei following injections in the midbrain, it is likely that many of the retrogradely labeled cells located in the midbrain, other than those found in the dorsal and ventral tegmental nuclei, have projections to structures adjacent to the MB.

Based on the present findings and the results of previous studies (Hayakawa and Zyo, '84; Liu et al., '84; Petrovickjl, '85; Takeuchi et al., '85; Shibata, '87), it is apparent that the distributions of afferent fibers in the MB which originate from different parts of the midbrain tend to terminate within the boundaries of specific subnuclei in the MB.

For example, the anterior ventral tegmental nucleus projects mainly to the pars medianus of the medial mamillary nucleus bilaterally, the dorsolateral part of the posterior ventral tegmental nucleus projects to the pars medialis and pars posterior ipsilaterally, the ventromedial part of the posterior ventral tegmental nucleus projects to the pars lateralis and pars basalis ipsilaterally, and the dorsal tegmental nucleus projects to the lateral mamillary nucleus ipsilaterally.
In contrast, afferents from the subicular complex form horizontal layers which spread across the medial nucleus bilaterally.

Thus, the horizontal distribution of afferent fibers from the subicular complex appears to be orthogonally oriented to the somewhat subnuclear-specific organization of afferent projections which originate from the midbrain tegmentum and the topographical MB projection to the anterior thalamus (Cruce, '75).

Furthermore, the distribution of afferent fibers in the pars medianus which originates from the anterior ventral tegmental nucleus overlaps almost exclusively and precisely with that which originates from the medial prefrontal cortex.
Descending projection neurons in the MB
The present results show that at least 80-90% of the cells in the medial and lateral mamillary nuclei were retrogradely labeled following injections of WGA-HRP into the midbrain.
A similar percentage of perikarya in the MB were retrogradely labeled following injections of WGA-HRP into the anterior thalamus (Takeuchi et al., '85).

Furthermore, the ultrastructural features of retrogradely labeled neurons in the present study were identical to those of neurons in the MB which were retrogradely labeled after anterior thalamic injections (Takeuchi et al., '85) and MB neurons of the normal rat (Allen and Hopkins, '88).
Thus, it is appears likely that most neurons in the medial and lateral mamillary nuclei project to the midbrain tegmentum as well as to the anterior thalamus.

Strong evidence in support of this finding was provided in the fluorescent retrograde double-labeling experiments of Takeuchi et al. ('85) which demonstrated that most cells in the medial and lateral mamillary nuclei were double labeled following injections of different fluorescent dyes into the anterior thalamus and midbrain.
Fine structure of MB merents
The present results provide the first electron microscopic analysis of the synaptic relationships of axon terminals in the MB which arise from identified sources.

Based on the present findings, it is apparent that cells in the MB receive afferent fibers from cortical and brainstem regions which have different synaptic morphologies and terminate for the most part on different regions of the neuron (see summary diagram, Fig. 20).

Afferent fibers which originate in the subicular complex and the medial prefrontal cortex are characterized by round vesicles and form asymmetric synaptic junctions (RA) with distal dendrites and dendritic spines.

In contrast, afferent fibers which originate from the dorsal and ventral tegmental nuclei are characterized by pleomorphic vesicles and form symmetric synaptic junctions (PS) with neuronal somata and proximal dendrites as well as distal dendrites and dendritic spines.

The distributions of RA and PS synapses observed in the present study in which histochemical procedures were applied to the tissues correspond with the distributions of RA and PS synapses observed in the MB of the normal rat (Allen and Hopkins, '88).
There is evidence indicating that afferents from the subicular complex may have an excitatory influence on MB neurons.
Parmeggiani et al. ('71) and Poletti et al. ('73) have recorded excitatory responses from mamillary neurons following stimulation of the hippocampal formation.

In addition, significant decreases in the high-affinity uptake of the excitatory amino acid glutamate in the MB have been measured following fornix transection (Storm-Mathisen and Opsahl, '78; Walaas and Fonnum, '80) and hippocampal extirpation (Nitsch et al., '79).

Thus, the present findings are consistent with the possibility that RA synapses which originate from the subicular complex have an excitatory influence over MB neurons and use glutamate as a neurotransmitter.

With respect to the effect afferents from the midbrain tegmentum may have on ME3 neurons, Mugnaini and Oertel ('85) have indicated that numerous cells in the dorsal and ventral tegmental nuclei are immunoreactive for an antibody directed against glutamic acid decarboxylase (GAD), the synthesizing enzyme for the inhibitory amino acid GABA.
In addition, Mugnaini and Oertel ('85) have also indicated that moderate to low levels of GAD-positive fibers are present in the neuropil of the MB.

Immunocytochemical studies in other regions of the central nervous system (McLaughlin et al., '74; Ribak, '78; Ribak et al., '79; Somogyi et al., '83) have indicated that GAD-positive axon terminals are of the PS type.
Furthermore, Andersen et al. ('64), Ito et al. ('641, and Uchizono ('65, '67) have shown that PS synapses in the cerebellum are inhibitory.
Thus, it is possible that afferents from the dorsal and ventral tegmental nuclei may form inhibitory PS-type synapses on mamillary neurons and may use GABA as a neurotransmitter.
Neural circuitry of the MB
The medial and lateral mamillary nuclei have complex synaptic connections with cortical, subcortical, and brainstem structures.
From a comparison of the afferent and efferent connections of the MB, the medial and lateral mamillary nuclei can be seen as participating in at least PREFRONTAL CORTEX AFFERENTS
MIDBRAIN AFFERENTS
three distinct neural circuits with the medial prefrontal cortex, subicular complex, and the midbrain tegmentum (Fig. 21).
For example, the medial mamillary nucleus, but not the lateral nucleus, receives afferent projections from the dorsal and ventral subiculum, medial prefrontal cortex, and ventral tegmental nucleus.
In contrast, the lateral mamillary nucleus receives major afferent fibers from the presubiculum, parasubiculum, and dorsal tegmental nucleus.

In addition, the medial nucleus has ascending projections to the anteromedial and anteroventral thalamic nuclei and descending projections to the ventral tegmental nucleus ipsilaterally, whereas the lateral nucleus has ascending projections to the anterodorsal thalamic nucleus bilaterally and descending projections to the dorsal tegmental nucleus ipsilaterally.

Although both the medial and lateral mamillary nuclei have descending projections to the nucleus reticularis tegmenti pontis and medial pontine nuclei, these projections appear to be topographically organized and essentially nonoverlapping in these regions (Hopkins et al., '85; Aas and Brodal, '88).

Therefore, it may be advantageous to consider the MB as consisting of a medial and a lateral nucleus which are distinguished not only by the size and morphology of their cells (Allen and Hopkins, '88) but also by the anatomical organization of their afferent and efferent connections.
Furthermore, the connections of the medial mamillary nucleus are organized such that it contains cell groups which are part of at least two quite separate neural circuits.
One of these circuits is the so-called "Papez circuit" (MacLean, '52).

Papez ('37) reasoned that the circuitous flow of impulses from the cingulate cortex which passes through the hippocampus, MB, and anterior thalamus before returning to the cingulate cortex may form an anatomical substrate for emotion.
However, the present results indicate that the pars medianus is not part of this pathway but instead receives a substantial input from the medial prefrontal cortex.

Anatomical (Van der Kooy et al., '82; Terreyberry and Neafsey, '87) and physiological (Burns et al., '83; Terreyberry and Neafsey, '84; Hurley-Gius and Neafsey, '86) studies have indicated that the medial prefrontal cortex may mediate respiratory, cardiovascular, and gastric activity through its connections with the nucleus of the solitary tract.

In keeping with the separation of neural circuits, the pars medianus projects to the anteromedial thalamic nucleus (Cruce, '75; Watanabe and Kawana, '80; Seki and Zyo, '84), which in turn projects to the medial prefrontal cortex (Beckstead, '76; Krettek and Price, '77; Divac et al., '78).
Thus, impulses may follow a circuitous route from the medial prefrontal cortex to the medial mamillary nucleus, to the anterior thalamus, and back to the medial prefrontal cortex.
Both the "Papez circuit" and the medial prefrontal cortex-MB circuit are influenced by afferent fibers which reach the MB from different parts of the ventral tegmental nucleus.

Cells in the anterior ventral tegmental nucleus project mainly to the pars medianus and cells in the posterior ventral tegmental nucleus project to the other subnuclei of the medial mamillary nucleus.
Thus, these two neural pathways are also distinguished by the fact that they each receive afferent information from different sources in the midbrain.

In addition, other circuits which include the premamillary, supramamillary, and tuberomamillary nuclei (Allen and Hopkins, '87) may also play a role or be related to the neural processing which occurs in MB circuits.

These three different anatomical circuits which include different subnuclei of the MB maybe reflected in differences among the functional activities of the medial and lateral mamillary nuclei as well.

Clinical (Victor et al., '71; Mair et al., '79) and experimental studies (Rosenstock et al., '77; Aggleton and Mishkin, '85) have described impairments in learning and memory in patients or subjects following damage to the medial mamillary nucleus.
In another aspect, cells in the medial mamillary nucleus of the normal rat have significantly higher levels of 2-deoxyglucose uptake than cells located in the lateral nucleus (Sokoloff et al., '77).

Therefore, it appears that cell groups in the medial and lateral nuclei have differences in functional and metabolic activities as well as differences in their afferent and efferent connections such as those elucidated in the present study.
